1. é¦–å…ˆæˆ‘ä»¬è¦å…³æ³¨ä¸€ä¸ªåœ°å€ 0xf387D73Dca6a29c603d8A9f00B3E2B0Ad029FcB5 ï¼Œè¯¥åœ°å€ä»35hå‰ï¼Œåˆ†å¤šç¬”ä»ç«å¸ææ¬¾ æ¥è¿‘60M wlfi ï¼ˆå·®3ä¸ªï¼‰ï¼Œå­˜å…¥å¸å®‰ï¼Œå…·ä½“çš„è½¬è´¦äº¤æ˜“ã€‚ etherscan.io/address/0xf387dâ€¦

æˆ‘å…¶å®å»ºè®®è¿˜æ˜¯è®¤äº†è€é¼ ä»“ï¼Œå–å¸æ˜¯å¯ä»¥çš„ï¼Œå‰æœŸæ‰“äº†é¢„å”®ï¼Œæœ‰äº†åˆ©æ¶¦ï¼Œéš¾é“ä¸èƒ½å–å—ï¼Ÿæˆ‘è‡ªå·±ä¹Ÿå–äº†ä¸€å¤§åŠçš„è§£é”ç­¹ç ã€‚å¦‚æœå•çº¯å› ä¸ºä»–äººæ˜¯å¤§æˆ·ï¼Œè€Œä¸è®©å–ï¼Œé‚£å°±æ˜¯é“å¾·ç»‘æ¶äº†ã€‚ä½†æ˜¯å¦‚æœè®¤äº†æ˜¯æŒªç”¨ç”¨æˆ·èµ„äº§ï¼Œé‚£å¯å°±è¦å¼€å§‹æå¸è¿åŠ¨äº†ï¼Œä¸‡ä¸€ä¼¤å®³åˆ°å¤§ç›˜ï¼Œé‚£ä¼šè¢«å–·çš„æ›´æƒ¨ã€‚

A deep dive on-chain to uncover
@justinsuntron and what exactly he did to end up blacklisted by $WLFI:
A few hours ago, Justin Sunâ€™s address was added to the blacklist by the @worldlibertyfi team. His WLFI holdings â€” both locked and unlocked â€” are now completely frozen. So what did he do to anger the project team, going from cozy ties to a hard blacklist? While CEXs are notorious black boxes and we canâ€™t trace internal fund flows, we can dissect the available on-chain data.

1. First, pay attention to address 0xf387D73Dca6a29c603d8A9f00B3E2B0Ad029FcB5. About 35 hours ago, this address withdrew ~60M WLFI (just 3 short) from Huobi in multiple batches and deposited them into Binance. (See details: etherscan.io/address/0xf387dâ€¦)

2. Tracing this address further, we clearly see multiple interactions with Binance (Figure 1): deposits of EIGEN, USDT, and now WLFI. Letâ€™s start the tracking from EIGEN.

3. From Figure 1: Huobi â†’ Binance deposits of EIGEN totaled 5,374,260 (ignoring decimals). Checking the corresponding time, we find matching large EIGEN deposits into Huobi (etherscan.io/advanced-filterâ€¦). In Figure 2, we clearly see six deposits over 100k EIGEN on the same day. Adding them up? The total matches exactly the EIGEN that went into Binance.

4. So whose EIGEN stash was this? Figure 3 shows that the largest source address (>2M) came directly from Justin Sun. Other addresses have also been identified in past EIGENLayer airdrops as belonging to him.

5. The conclusion is simple: this ~60M WLFI was Justin Sunâ€™s deposit into Binance. Whether he sold it or not, only he and Binance know.

6. To summarize: Sun claimed it was just â€œsmall test transactions.â€ And on-chain data shows he never moved such a huge WLFI amount from his public addresses into Huobi. So where did the 60M WLFI come from? Was it customer WLFI diverted to Binance for â€˜testingâ€™, or a secret stash?

If the former: thatâ€™s a crime.

If the latter: itâ€™s just the same old trickery.
